Name: AuditResult.RuleFoundInPolicies
Description: The policy was found in Conditional Access by a deep review of all polices available.

Name: AuditResult.RuleNotFoundInPolicies
Description: The policy was not found in  Conditional Access possibly too low a risk level or its just not there

Name: AuditResult.NoAccess
Description: User cannot audit with current rights.  Try the Senserva Client.

Name: AuditResult.AssignedPlanReview
Description: The collection of service plans associated with the tenant.

Name: AuditResult.RuleUsage
Description: Rule Audited to see if its used

Name: AuditResult.DataEcho
Description: Audit only provides information.

Name: AuditResult.SubscriptionPastDue
Description: Your Azure subscription has an outstanding payment pending. Your subscription is still active but failure to pay the dues may result in subscription being disabled.

Name: AuditResult.SubscriptionDisabled
Description: Your Azure subscription is disabled and can no longer be used to create or manage Azure resources.

Name: AuditResult.SubscriptionWarned
Description: A subscription may be in warned state if its past due canceled by user or if the subscription has expired

Name: AuditResult.SubscriptionDeleted
Description: Your Azure subscription has been deleted along with all underlying resources/data.

Name: AuditResult.SpendingLimitOff
Description: The spending limit in Azure prevents spending over your credit amount.

Name: AuditResult.CurrentPeriodOff
Description: The spending limit in Azure prevents spending over your credit amount.

Name: AuditResult.SpendingLimitOn
Description: The spending limit in Azure prevents spending over your credit amount.

Name: AuditResult.AuthMethodReview
Description: Senserva provides important security related data for you to review.

Name: AuditResult.IgnoredSigninRisk
Description: Check Ignored because its not considered important but review in case you think it is important.

Name: AuditResult.HiddenSigninRisk
Description: In Azure a hidden risk level means that a user or sign-in was not enabled for Entra Identity Protection which is why their risk level is not displayed; essentially the system isn't actively monitoring that user for potential risks and this information is typically only available to users with an Entra Premium P2 license

Name: AuditResult.UserDirectlyExcludedInPolicy
Description: User directly named in a rule

Name: AuditResult.OperatingSystemVersion
Description: Versions need to be managed

Name: AuditResult.DeviceStale
Description: Device has not been used recently

Name: AuditResult.DeviceNotStale
Description: Device has been used recently

Name: AuditResult.DeviceCompliant
Description: A device that meets the security standards set by a company's Conditional Access policies meaning it has been configured and managed to satisfy specific requirements like encryption password complexity and updates allowing it to access sensitive company resources like email and applications without restriction.

Name: AuditResult.DeviceNotCompliant
Description: A  device that meets the security standards set by a company's Conditional Access policies meaning it has been configured and managed to satisfy specific requirements like encryption password complexity and updates allowing it to access sensitive company resources like email and applications without restriction.

Name: AuditResult.DeviceIsManaged
Description: A policy within Microsoft Entra ID that only allows access to company resources like email or applications from devices that are actively managed and considered compliant by the organization's mobile device management (MDM) system.

Name: AuditResult.DeviceIsNotManaged
Description: A policy within Microsoft Entra ID that only allows access to company resources like email or applications from devices that are actively managed and considered compliant by the organization's mobile device management (MDM) system.

Name: AuditResult.SenservaAttributes
Description: A rooted device is a device that has been unlocked or jailbroken to give the user more control over the device's operating system

Name: AuditResult.DeviceIsNotRooted
Description: A rooted device is a device that has been unlocked or jailbroken to give the user more control over the device's operating system

Name: AuditResult.ConditionalAccessCounts
Description: Report on how Conditional Access is being used.

Name: AuditResult.SoftwareOneTimePasscode
Description: In Azure refers to a temporary unique code generated by a software application on a user's device like the Microsoft Authenticator app which is used as an extra layer of security during login to verify their identity essentially acting as a second factor in multi-factor authentication (MFA) within Entra; this code is typically time-sensitive and expires after a short period.

Name: AuditResult.WindowsHelloforBusiness
Description: Windows Hello for Business is a Microsoft feature that allows users to sign into their work devices using biometric authentication like facial recognition or fingerprint scans instead of a traditional password

Name: AuditResult.Fido2
Description: Users can register a passkey (FIDO2) and choose it as their primary sign-in method. With a hardware device that handles the authentication the security of an account is increased as there's no password that can be exposed or guessed.

Name: AuditResult.MicrosoftAuthenticatorPasswordless
Description: Microsoft Authenticator can be used to sign in to any Microsoft Entra account without using a password. Microsoft Authenticator uses key-based authentication to enable a user credential that is tied to a device where the device uses a PIN or biometric. Windows Hello for Business uses a similar technology. This authentication technology can be used on any device platform including mobile.

Name: AuditResult.PassKeyDeviceBound
Description: Refers to a type of passkey within the Microsoft Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) system that is specifically tied to a single device meaning it cannot be used on any other device and is stored locally on that device providing enhanced security by preventing unauthorized access even if someone gains knowledge of the passkey itself due to its device-specific nature.

Name: AuditResult.MicrosoftAuthenticatorPush
Description: The Authenticator app can help prevent unauthorized access to accounts and stop fraudulent transactions by pushing a notification to your smartphone or tablet. Users view the notification and if it's legitimate select Verify. Otherwise they can select Deny

Name: AuditResult.EmailForAdminPreferedAuthenticationMethod
Description: Compared to methods like biometrics or security keys email authentication can be considered less secure.

Name: AuditResult.EmailForPreferedAuthenticationMethod
Description: Compared to methods like biometrics or security keys email authentication can be considered less secure.

Name: AuditResult.UnknownAuthenticationMethod
Description: Review method

Name: AuditResult.PasswordPreferedAuthenticationMethod
Description: The primary way a user is expected to log in to a system is by entering their username and password although this is generally considered a less secure option compared to other methods like multi-factor authentication or passwordless logins.

Name: AuditResult.PasswordForAdminPreferedAuthenticationMethod
Description: The primary way a user is expected to log in to a system is by entering their username and password although this is generally considered a less secure option compared to other methods like multi-factor authentication or passwordless logins.

Name: AuditResult.PhoneAppNotification
Description: A multi-factor authentication (MFA) method that sends a notification to a user's mobile app to prompt for approval or rejection. It's used in conjunction with the Microsoft Authenticator app

Name: AuditResult.SmsForPreferedAuthenticationMethod
Description: While convenient SMS authentication is not considered the most secure method due to potential vulnerabilities like SIM swapping or phishing attacks where someone could intercept the verification code.

Name: AuditResult.SmsForAdminPreferedAuthenticationMethod
Description: While convenient SMS authentication is not considered the most secure method due to potential vulnerabilities like SIM swapping or phishing attacks where someone could intercept the verification code.

Name: AuditResult.Enabled
Description: Setting or feature is enabled

Name: AuditResult.EnabledForAllUsersAndApplications
Description: Conditional Access Setting is for All Users and All Applications an no specific includes

Name: AuditResult.NotEnabled
Description: Setting or feature is not enabled

Name: AuditResult.NotEnabledForAdmin
Description: Setting or feature is not enabled for an Entra admin. administrators should have significantly more security measures applied to their accounts compared to regular users because they have elevated privileges that allow them to access and modify critical systems and data making them a high-value target for attackers.

Name: AuditResult.EnabledForAdmin
Description: Setting or feature is enabled for an Entra admin. administrators should have significantly more security measures applied to their accounts compared to regular users because they have elevated privileges that allow them to access and modify critical systems and data making them a high-value target for attackers.

Name: AuditResult.State
Description: State is set to

Name: AuditResult.DeviceOnExcludedList
Description: Informational

Name: AuditResult.DeviceOnIncludedList
Description: Informational

Name: AuditResult.DeviceExcludedByFilter
Description: Informational

Name: AuditResult.DeviceIncludedByFilter
Description: Informational

Name: AuditResult.PimChange
Description: Change to a PIM setting

Name: AuditResult.UserExcludedViaRole
Description: Informational

Name: AuditResult.UserNotExcludedViaAnyRole
Description: Informational

Name: AuditResult.UserNotExcludedViaAnyGroup
Description: Informational

Name: AuditResult.UserExcludedViaGroup
Description: Informational

Name: AuditResult.UserModificationAttempt
Description: Someone tried to change a user setting this is likely ok but should be reviewed.

Name: AuditResult.RollManagementChange
Description: Review and monitor

Name: AuditResult.ResourceManagementChange
Description: Review and monitor

Name: AuditResult.AuthorizationChange
Description: Review and monitor

Name: AuditResult.AuthenticationChange
Description: Review and monitor

Name: AuditResult.UserManagementChange
Description: Review and monitor

Name: AuditResult.ApplicationManagementChange
Description: Review and monitor

Name: AuditResult.DeviceChange
Description: Review and monitor

Name: AuditResult.GroupManagementChange
Description: Review and monitor

Name: AuditResult.DirectoryManagementChange
Description: Review and monitor

Name: AuditResult.OtherChange
Description: Review and monitor

Name: AuditResult.PolicyChange
Description: Review and monitor

Name: AuditResult.FailedConditionalAccessChange
Description: Review and monitor

Name: AuditResult.ConditionalAccessChange
Description: Review and monitor

Name: AuditResult.PolicyNotMatchedByRule
Description: Conditional Access policy not matched by reviewing how it would work

Name: AuditResult.PolicyMatchedByRule
Description: This Policy would likely be used by the named User. Senserva simulates Conditional Access Policy usage to see what Policies apply to who and what. Think of it as advanced Conditional Access What If Tool.

Name: AuditResult.TrackActivity
Description: Logging an activity for reference

Name: AuditResult.NeedsManualAudit
Description: More review needed by a qualified admin

Name: AuditResult.PolicyNeverUsedForSignin
Description: Conditional Access policy is not being used based on sign in log policy needs a review

Name: AuditResult.PolicyUsedForSignin
Description: Conditional Access policy is being used based on sign in log policy needs a review

Name: AuditResult.InternalError
Description: Audit Issue

Name: AuditResult.CannotRead
Description: No Audit Performed - Cannot Read Target - Check Permissions

Name: AuditResult.IncludedRoleAlsoExcluded
Description: Included role also excluded in a policy review needed

Name: AuditResult.UserWithOldMfa
Description: Conditional Access recommended

Name: AuditGroup.User
Description: an individual identity within an organization essentially representing a person who can access applications and resources within the platform with different user types like member (internal employee) and guest (external collaborator) depending on their access level and how they authenticate.

Name: AuditGroup.PerUserMfa
Description: A setting within Microsoft Azure Active Directory where multi-factor authentication (MFA) is enabled individually for each user meaning every time a user logs in they will be prompted to provide a second verification method like a code sent to their phone regardless of where they are signing in from essentially forcing them to use MFA on every login unless specific exceptions are configured; it's considered a legacy method as Microsoft now recommends using Conditional Access policies for more granular control over MFA requirements based on various factors like location and application access.

Name: AuditGroup.Organization
Description: An organization's representation in Entra ID. An organization receives and owns an Entra ID tenant when it signs up for a Microsoft cloud service like Azure.

Name: AuditGroup.UnifiedRoleManagementPolicy
Description: A policy within the Microsoft Entra suite that governs how users are assigned roles and permissions across different Microsoft services essentially providing a centralized way to manage access control for various applications and resources within an organization

Name: AuditGroup.ConditionalAccess
Description: A security feature within Microsoft Entra ID that allows administrators to control access to applications and resources based on specific conditions like user identity location device compliance and more essentially deciding who can access what and under which circumstances enhancing overall security by preventing unauthorized access to sensitive data.

Name: AuditGroup.SecureScore
Description: A numerical value within Microsoft Entra ID that measures how well an organization aligns with Microsoft's security recommendations for identity management essentially acting as a gauge of the organization's overall identity security posture with a higher score indicating better security practices implemented based on Microsoft's best practices; you can access and review recommended actions to improve your score within the Microsoft Entra portal.

Name: AuditGroup.DirectoryRole
Description: In Microsoft Entra ID if another administrator or non-administrator needs to manage Microsoft Entra resources you assign them a Microsoft Entra role that provides the permissions they need. For example you can assign roles to allow adding or changing users resetting user passwords managing user licenses or managing domain names

Name: AuditGroup.Device
Description: The goal of Microsoft Entra registered - also known as Workplace joined - devices is to provide your users with support for bring your own device (BYOD) or mobile device scenarios. In these scenarios a user can access your organization's resources using a personal device.

Name: AuditGroup.Group
Description: With Microsoft Entra groups you can grant access and permissions to a group of users instead of for each individual user. Limiting access to Microsoft Entra resources to only those users who need access is one of the core security principles of Zero Trust.

Name: AuditGroup.Location
Description: Determines the country a user is operating from which can affect license availability feature availability data center location and data governanc

Name: AuditGroup.RiskyUser
Description: A user account that is considered to be at risk of compromise

Name: AuditGroup.RiskDetection
Description: Microsoft Entra ID Protection provides organizations with information to suspicious activity in their tenant and allows them to respond quickly to prevent further risk occurring.

Name: AuditGroup.ServicePrincipal
Description: An identity that allows applications hosted services and automated tools to access Azure resources. It acts as the application's identity and controls what resources the application can access and who can access them

Name: AuditType.None
Description: No Details

Name: AuditType.Organization
Description: An organization represents a business entity that is using Microsoft cloud offerings typically identified by one or more public Domain Name System (DNS) domain names such as contoso.com. The organization is a container for subscriptions.

Name: AuditType.Subscription
Description: A subscription is an agreement with Microsoft to use one or more Microsoft cloud platforms or services for which charges accrue based on either a per-user license fee or on cloud-based resource consumption.

Name: AuditType.Tenant
Description: A Microsoft Entra tenant is a specific instance of Microsoft Entra ID containing accounts and groups.

Name: AuditType.UserRegistrationDetails
Description: Azure User Registration Details refers to information about a user's registered authentication methods within Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) including details like whether they have registered for multi-factor authentication (MFA) self-service password reset (SSPR) and which specific methods they are using to authenticate such as email phone number or security key; essentially it provides a snapshot of how a user has set up their login security within Azure

Name: AuditType.SubscribedSku
Description: Represents information about a service SKU that a company is subscribed to.

Name: AuditType.LicenseDetailsForUser
Description: Many Microsoft Entra services require you to license each of your users.

Name: AuditType.AssignedLicensesForUser
Description: Many Microsoft Entra services require you to license each of your users.

Name: AuditType.ProvisionedPlans
Description: Azure provisioned plans are a variety of Azure services that allocate resources for specific purposes

Name: AuditType.AssignedPlanForUser
Description: Azure provisioned plans are a variety of Azure services that allocate resources for specific purposes

Name: AuditType.ProvisionedPlanForUser
Description: Azure provisioned plans are a variety of Azure services that allocate resources for specific purposes

Name: AuditType.VerifiedDomains
Description: Azure Verified Domains are domains that have been validated as belonging to a user or organization

Name: AuditType.Info
Description: Information Only

Name: AuditType.AssignedPlans
Description: Assigned Plans are The collection of service plans associated with the tenant.

Name: AuditType.EntraIdPim
Description: Privileged Identity Management (PIM) is a service in Microsoft Entra ID that enables you to manage control and monitor access to important resources in your organization

Name: AuditType.UserActivity
Description: Microsoft Entra logs all sign-ins into a Microsoft Entra tenant which includes your internal apps and resources. As an IT administrator you need to know what the sign-in log details mean so that you can interpret the log values correctly.

Name: AuditType.ApplicationActivity
Description: Microsoft Entra logs all sign-ins into an Azure tenant for compliance purposes. As an IT administrator you need to know what the values in the sign-in logs mean so that you can interpret the log values correctly.

Name: AuditType.ConfigurationError
Description: Improper Entra ID Configurations Found.

Name: AuditType.UsersDevice
Description: A user's device refers to any personal device like a computer phone or tablet that a user has registered with their Microsoft Entra account allowing them to access organizational resources and enabling administrators to manage device security and access controls based on the device's state and identity within the system; essentially it's a way to link a user to their specific device for identity management purposes.

Name: AuditType.IsPasswordlessCapable
Description: A user account within the Microsoft Entra ID system is able to log in without using a traditional password instead relying on alternative methods like Windows Hello for Business Microsoft Authenticator app or FIDO2 security keys for authentication essentially enabling a passwordless login experience

Name: AuditType.IsSsprCapable
Description: Indicates whether the user has registered the required number of authentication methods for self-service password reset and the user is allowed to perform self-service password reset by policy

Name: AuditType.IsSsprEnabled
Description: Indicates whether the user is allowed to perform self-service password reset by policy. The user may not necessarily have registered the required number of authentication methods for self-service password reset

Name: AuditType.IsSsprRegistered
Description: A user is considered registered for Self-service Password Reset (SSPR) when they have registered the required number of methods to reset their password.

Name: AuditType.IsMfaCapable
Description: Indicates whether the user has registered a strong authentication method for multifactor authentication. Even if a user has registered an MFA method their IsMfaCapable status can be affected by their organization's MFA policies which can restrict or enable MFA usage for specific users

Name: AuditType.IsMfaRegistered
Description: Indicates whether the user has registered a strong authentication method for multifactor authentication. The method may not necessarily be allowed by the authentication methods policy. sMfaRegistered. Yes. boolean. Indicates whether the user already enrolled a method for multi-factor authentication. If the value is set to false  the Conditional Access policy evaluation returns a block challenge if action is required.

Name: AuditType.SystemPreferredAuthenticationMethod
Description: Authentication methods that the system determined to be the most secure authentication methods among the registered methods for second factor authentication

Name: AuditType.IsSystemPreferredAuthenticationMethodEnabled
Description: Indicates whether system preferred authentication method is enabled. If enabled the system dynamically determines the most secure authentication method among the methods registered by the user.

Name: AuditType.UserRiskLevelInPolicy
Description: Organizations must decide the level of risk they want to require access control on balancing user experience and security posture. Choosing to apply access control on a High risk level reduces the number of times a policy is triggered and minimizes friction for users. However it excludes Low and Medium risks from the policy which might not block an attacker from exploiting a compromised identity.

Name: AuditType.FailedEntraOperation
Description: A failed Microsoft Entra activity log should be reviewed and monitored.

Name: AuditType.SucessfulEntraOperation
Description: A sucessfaul Microsoft Entra activity log could reflect a change that needs to be reviewed.

Name: AuditType.ConditionalAccessAuditForDevice
Description: Conditional Access audit for devices allows administrators to create policies that control access to applications and resources based on certain conditions including device compliance.

Name: AuditType.AuditForDevice
Description: Microsoft Intune device compliance policies can evaluate the status of managed devices to ensure they meet your requirements before you grant them  to your organization's apps and services.

Name: AuditType.ConditionalAccessAuditForUser
Description: Reviews Polices from a user perspective.

Name: AuditType.RiskyUser
Description: Microsoft Entra ID Protection provides organizations with reporting they can use to investigate identity risks in their environment.

Name: AuditType.UserSignIn
Description: Microsoft Entra logs all sign-ins into a Microsoft Entra tenant which includes your internal apps and resources. As an IT administrator you need to know what the sign-in log details mean.

Name: AuditType.SigninRiskLevel
Description: Requiring access control when risk level is low introduces more friction and user interrupts than medium or high.

Name: AuditType.RequireMfaForUserWithRoles
Description: Accounts that are assigned administrative rights are targeted by attackers. Requiring multifactor authentication (MFA) on those accounts is an easy way to reduce the risk of those accounts being compromised.

Name: AuditType.RequireMfaForUntrustedLocation
Description: Within Conditional Access you can define named locations which represent trusted IP ranges or geographic areas to exclude from the MFA requirement

Name: AuditType.RequireMfaAndPasswordChangeForSignInRisk
Description: Microsoft works with researchers law enforcement various security teams at Microsoft and other trusted sources to find leaked username and password pairs.

Name: AuditType.RequireBlockLegacyExchangeActiveSync
Description: Microsoft recommends that organizations block authentication requests using legacy protocols that don't support multifactor authentication.

Name: AuditType.RequireBlockLegacyOther
Description: Microsoft recommends that organizations block authentication requests using legacy protocols that don't support multifactor authentication.

Name: AuditType.BlockPlatformsAndroid
Description: Android based Rule

Name: AuditType.BlockAdminAccessFromUnmangedDevices
Description: Require Admins to login from a Managed Device

Name: AuditType.RequireBlockFromUntrustedCountries
Description: With the location condition in Conditional Access you can control access to your cloud apps based on the network location of a user block all countries you do not need..

Name: AuditType.RequireBlockFromHighRiskCountries
Description: With the location condition in Conditional Access you can control access to your cloud apps based on the network location of a user.

Name: AuditType.PolicyBlocksAllButAllowedCountries
Description: This policy blocks everything expect those coming from allowed countries. Only allow countries are sure you need.

Name: AuditType.PolicyOnlyAllowesApprovedCountries
Description: This policy only enables allowed countries.

Name: AuditType.PolicyIncludedLocation
Description: This location is in an included list and the policy is not a block if enabled.  review and block access from countries/regions where your organization knows traffic shouldn't come from.

Name: AuditType.PolicyIncludedLocationHasUnwantedCountry
Description: This location is in an included list but it contains an unapproved country. Review and block access from countries/regions where your organization knows traffic shouldn't come from.

Name: AuditType.RequireMfaAndPasswordChangeForRiskyUsers
Description: Microsoft works with researchers law enforcement various security teams at Microsoft and other trusted sources to find leaked username and password pairs.

Name: AuditType.ExcludeGuestsOrExternalUsers
Description: Internal guests or external users excluded from the policy scope. You need to review this state to make sure it matches your policies.

Name: AuditType.NeedsMoreReview
Description: More Review Needed by an Admin to make a security recommendation

Name: AuditType.PolicyActivity
Description: Reviews how a Conditional Access Rules is being used or not being used.

Name: AuditType.ConditionalAccessUsage
Description: Conditional Access Audit of how Conditional is being used.

Name: AuditType.AuditForGroup
Description: Audit a group this release only reports on group states.

Name: AuditType.AuditForRole
Description: Audit a role this release only reports on role states.

Name: AuditType.PerUserMfa
Description: For Microsoft Entra ID Free tenants without Conditional Access you can use security defaults to protect users as well. With Per User MFA users are prompted for MFA as needed but you can't define your own rules to control the behavior. If needed you can instead enable each account for per-user Microsoft Entra MFA. When you enable users individually they perform MFA each time they sign in.

Name: AuditRisk.Info
Description: Information for research and tracking history. There is no known security issues but the information is important to security and should be reviewed and understood and should map to your own policies.

Name: AuditRisk.Pass
Description: A passed security risk refers to a potential security threat that has been assessed and deemed acceptable by an organization meaning they have decided to accept the likelihood and potential impact of the risk often after implementing mitigating controls to manage it rather than actively attempting to eliminate it completely.

Name: AuditRisk.Warning
Description: A low risk is situation where the potential for damage or harm from a security threat is considered minimal with a low likelihood of a breach occurring and where any potential negative consequences would be relatively minor if a breach did happen; essentially a situation where the security threat is not likely to cause significant disruption or harm.

Name: AuditRisk.LowRisk
Description: A low risk is situation where the potential for damage or harm from a security threat is considered minimal with a low likelihood of a breach occurring and where any potential negative consequences would be relatively minor if a breach did happen; essentially a situation where the security threat is not likely to cause significant disruption or harm.

Name: AuditRisk.MediumRisk
Description: A medium security risk refers to a potential threat or vulnerability that if exploited could cause moderate damage or disruption meaning the impact would be noticeable but not catastrophic and the likelihood of the threat occurring is considered neither highly probable nor highly unlikely.

Name: AuditRisk.HighRisk
Description: A high security risk refers to a situation where the potential for damage or loss from a security threat is significant meaning there is a high likelihood of a breach occurring and the consequences of that breach would be severe causing substantial disruption or harm to systems data or operations; essentially a high risk indicates a combination of a high probability of a threat occurring and a large potential impact if it does.

Name: AuditRisk.CriticalRisk
Description: A critical security risk refers to a potential security threat that if realized would have a severe and immediate impact on an organization often causing significant damage to operations data integrity or reputation usually characterized by a high likelihood of occurrence and high severity of consequences.
